verdict.summary: Git cannot automatically merge changes — both branches modified the same lines.

dead_ends.action: Accepting 'ours' or 'theirs' blindly for all files
dead_ends.why_fails: Discards one side's changes entirely without reviewing

dead_ends.action: Deleting the conflicting files and recreating them
dead_ends.why_fails: Loses git history; may miss important changes from either side

workarounds.action: Resolve manually: open conflicting files, choose correct code between <<<<<<< and >>>>>>>
workarounds.how: Use git diff to see both sides; remove conflict markers after resolving

workarounds.action: Use a merge tool: git mergetool — opens a visual diff/merge editor
workarounds.how: Configure with: git config merge.tool vimdiff

frequently_confused_with.distinction: 'CONFLICT (content)' indicates a Git merge conflict, while 'error' indicates a rejected Git push (remote has new commits).
'CONFLICT (content)' indicates a Git merge conflict, while 'error' indicates a branch or file not found in Git.
